src:
Presset øker
Mens presset øker mot president Trump hevder Washington Post justisminister William Barr skal ha nektet å forsvare ham offentlig i forbindelse med Ukraina-skandalen.
07 Nov 2019, 01:49 by Frode Andresen
Natt til torsdag melder Washington Post at president Donald Trump ba justisminister William Barr om å holde en pressekonferanse hvor han slo fast at presidenten ikke hadde brutt loven i forbindelse med telefonsamtalen med Ukrainas president, ifølge kilder som er kjent med hendelsen.
Forslaget skal ha blitt overlevert via tjenestemenn, og Barr skal ha avslått Trumps forslag umiddelbart. Trump skal ha nevnt Barrs avslag overfor medarbeidere de siste ukene, og skal ha sagt at han skulle ønske Barr ville holde pressekonferansen.
Trump skal ha fremmet sitt ønske like etter at en utskrift av samtalen mellom ham og Ukrainas president, Volodymyr Zelenskyj, ble frigitt i slutten av september.
Presset øker
I ukevis har Demokratene undersøkt hvorvidt president Trump holdt igjen omkring 400 millioner dollar i militærhjelp i et forsøk på å presse Ukraina til å åpne en etterforskning som ville sverte presidentkandidat Joe Biden.
For andre gang på to dager har offentligheten fått vite at to vitner hevder at militærhjelpen ble brukt som et pressmiddel for å få Ukraina til å åpne etterforskning.
Endret vitnesbyrd
Tirsdag ble det frigitt en oppdatert versjon av Gordon Sondlands vitnesbyrd. Sondland er USAs ambassadør til EU.

Der hevder Sondland at han hadde en samtale med Andriy Yermak, som er en betrodd rådgiver for Ukrainas president.

Sondland fortalte til Yermak at omkring 400 millioner dollar i militærhjelp sannsynligvis ville bli holdt igjen fram til landet kunngjorde at de ville åpne en korrupsjonsetterforskning, slik som de hadde diskutert, ifølge Sondlands vitnesbyrd.
Etterforskningen omfattet også et gasselskap med bånd til Joe Bidens sønn, Hunter Biden.
Støtter anklagene
Onsdag ble ambassadør Bill Taylors vitnesbyrd frigitt. Han hevder å ha blitt fortalt av to høytstående tjenestemenn i Trump-administrasjonen at president Trump ikke ville signere en «sjekk» på omkring 400 millioner dollar i militærhjelp til Ukraina, før landet hadde oppfylt sin del av avtalen.
Talyor hevder også at Trump i en samtale med Sondland skal ha sagt at han ville at Ukrainas president skulle «stå foran en mikrofon og si at han ville åpne etterforskning mot Biden og innblanding i 2016.-valget».
Taylor forklarte at han husker alt dette, fordi han har tatt notater og beholdt tekstmeldinger.
Trump nekter
President Trump har hele tiden nektet for å ha brukt militærhjelp som pressmiddel mot Ukraina. Han har også omtalt riksrettsprosessen mot ham som en «heksejakt».

Den kommende uka skal Bill Taylor, George Kent fra utenriksdepartementet og USAs tidligere Ukraina-ambassadør Marie Yovanovitch stille til TV-sendte høringer i forbindelse med riksrettssaken mot Trump.

Sistnevnte hevdet i sitt vitnesbyrd at USAs tidligere nasjonale sikkerhetsrådgiver, John Bolton, ba henne om å rapportere Trumps advokat, Rudy Giuliani, til sjefadvokaten for Det nasjonale sikkerhetsrådet. Årsaken skal ha vært at han var bekymret for Giulianis oppførsel overfor Ukraina.
Bolton har selv blitt bedt om å vitne for etterforskere knyttet til riksrettsprosessen, men har foreløpig ikke avklart om han vil gjøre det.
text:
The pressure is increasing
As pressure increases against President Trump, Washington Post Justice Minister William Barr claims to have refused to defend him publicly in connection with the Ukraine scandal.
07 Nov 2019, 01:49 by Frode Andresen
Night to Thursday, the Washington Post reports that President Donald Trump asked Justice Secretary William Barr to hold a press conference stating that the president had not broken the law in connection with the telephone conversation with the President of Ukraine, according to sources familiar with the incident.
The proposal should have been handed over through officials, and Barr should have rejected Trump's proposal immediately. Trump must have mentioned Barr's refusal to staff in recent weeks, and should have said he wished Barr would hold the press conference.
Trump should have expressed his wish shortly after a printout of the conversation between him and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyj was released in late September.
The pressure is increasing
For weeks, Democrats have been investigating whether President Trump detained about $ 400 million in military aid in an effort to pressure Ukraine to open an investigation that would blackmail Presidential candidate Joe Biden.
For the second time in two days, the public has been told that two witnesses claim that military aid was used as a means of pressure to get Ukraine to open an investigation.
Changed testimony
On Tuesday, an updated version of Gordon Sondland's testimony was released. Sondland is the US ambassador to the EU.

There, Sondland claims he had a conversation with Andriy Yermak, a trusted adviser to the President of Ukraine.

Sondland told Yermak that about $ 400 million in military aid would probably be withheld until the country announced that they would open a corruption investigation, as they had discussed, according to Sondland's testimony.
The investigation also included a gas company with ties to Joe Biden's son, Hunter Biden.
Supports the charges
On Wednesday, Ambassador Bill Taylor's testimony was released. He claims to have been told by two senior officials in the Trump administration that President Trump would not sign a $ 400 million "check" in military aid to Ukraine until the country fulfilled its part of the deal.
Talyor also claims that Trump, in a conversation with Sondland, should have said that he wanted the President of Ukraine to "stand in front of a microphone and say he would open investigations against Biden and interference in the 2016 election."
Taylor explained that he remembers all of this because he has taken notes and kept text messages.
Trump refuses
President Trump has repeatedly refused to use military aid as a press agent against Ukraine. He has also referred to the court process against him as a "witch hunt".

In the coming week, Bill Taylor, George Kent of the Department of Foreign Affairs and former US Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch will be sent to televised hearings in connection with the national court case against Trump.

The latter claimed in her testimony that former US security adviser John Bolton asked her to report Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, to the chief of the National Security Council. The reason must have been that he was worried about Giuliani's behavior towards Ukraine.
Bolton himself has been asked to testify for investigators linked to the judicial process, but has not yet decided whether he will.
